Ken,

Your answers to questions express your positions/opinions regarding 
=
the relative value of various topics...such as say the utility of 
Jeff's r=
eference to "building blocks." Your choices regarding 
published research a=
reas indicate areas of topical interest. Taken 
together, they could be cha=
racterized as an "agenda". Nothing secret, 
simply a "bent" towards a topic=
al sub-region. Don't misinterpret 
terminology.

Opinions are fine and have=
 their place, but the hope is that there 
will be a strong predisposition t=
owards empirical evidence to support 
assertions where possible.

Your effo=
rts have made repeated "claims" regarding indirect 
encoding's ability to d=
iscover patterns and variations.

In this context, I have been unable to ob=
serve two things:

1) What benchmark comparisons against commonly known pat=
terns, has 
Hyperneat been run against, so as to attempt quantification of =
it's 
relative ability to "discover patterns and variations"?

2) What comp=
utational cost benchmark comparisons against commonly 
known other tools us=
ed for "discovering patterns", has Hyperneat been 
run against, so as to at=
tempt quatification of it's relative 
computational cost to "discover patte=
rns and variations"?

The logical alternatives are that either you have or =
have not 
conducted these types of comparisons.

So which alternative is co=
rrect?

Andy
